conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the motion of the electron in the electric field using the given initial velocity and angle to determine the final velocity, then calculate the kinetic energy of the electron at point C.

The image shows two parallel metal plates, A and B, with opposite charges, creating a uniform electric field between them. An electron is injected from point O with an initial velocity v0 perpendicular to the electric field. The electron exits at point C, forming a 30° angle with its initial direction.
The electron is injected with an initial velocity v0 = 4 × 10^6 m/s perpendicular to the electric field.
The electron exits at point C, forming a 30° angle with its initial direction.
The horizontal component of the velocity at C is v0 cos(30°).
Using the cosine of 30°, which is √3/2, the horizontal velocity component is 4 × 10^6 × √3/2.
The vertical component of velocity at C is v0 sin(30°) = 4 × 10^6 × 1/2 = 2 × 10^6 m/s.
The final velocity vC is the vector sum of these components, but since the question focuses on the vertical component, we use vC = 2 × 10^6 m/s.
The kinetic energy of the electron at point C is calculated using the formula KE = 1/2 mvC^2.
Simplify to find the kinetic energy in Joules.
The kinetic energy of the electron at point C is 1.44 × 10^-19 J.
